column8: Curecanti National Recreation Area is a series of three reservoirs along the once wild Gunnison River. The reservoirs that make up Curecanti today are a destination for water-based recreation high in the Rocky Mountains. Best known for salmon and trout fishing\

column10: boating\
column11: camping\
column12:
and bird watching.<br />
There are a total of 7 beautiful hiking trails within the recreation area\
column13: all ranging from 1.5 miles to 6 miles. It's the perfect place to get away with your family\
column14: or build your endurance on a tough hike.

column16: Colorado. The recreation area is also accessed from CO Hwy 149 and CO Hwy 92.<br /><br />Source: National Park Service

column8:
This trail description is South-to-North. You will want a shuttle vehicle at the other trailhead off H75 Road. We used Peach Valley Road to drop the shuttle at that end.<br />
<br />
The Sidewinder Trail is a relentless\
column9: rocky\
column10: technical\
column11: physical adventure on the bike. There are very few extended climbs or downhills\
column12:
but my GPS still measured 2500' of climbing and 3000' of total descending by the time we were done.<br />
<br />
Mostly it is a constant mind-game of rocky\
column13: technical bike-handling tests. There are very few sections of fast cruising. The trail is extremely well-built though so the technical challenges are mostly rideable for a skilled rider. There were 6 of us on our ride and while we were all bucked-off at various places\
column14:
usually a couple of us would clean most features. <br />
<br />
As the name implies\
column15: the Sidewinder weaves in and out of many arroyos as you cling to the western edge of the Gunnison Gorge Wilderness Area. You will climb and descend these arroyos enjoying many slickrock drops and ledges along the way\
column16:
as well as about a thousand other rocky treats.<br />
<br />
The Sidewinder is not for beginners. I would imagine they would hate it and probably wind up hurt. For a rider loving a technical\
column17:
physical workout its one of the best trails I've ever ridden. It took our group 5 hours to ride the whole thing including all our breaks and lunch and all that. If you google "Sidewinder Trail" then you will find a map on the BLM website that shows the route and many other bailout options.<br />
<br />
Go ride it... you will not be disappointed.

The road will make a short descent to a signed interesection (not signed sidewinder though) where you will make a right turn. Very soon after that right you will find the beginning of the singletrack Sidewinder trail beginning its climb up the hillside on your left.

column8: Bountiful beauty covers Santa Rosa Island with 53\
column9: 000 acres of rolling grassy hills\
column10: deep canyons and white sand beaches. Santa Rosa is the second largest island of California&amp;#39;s Channel Islands\
column11: and is part of the Channel Islands National Park. The island landforms support a diverse array of plant and animal species including six plant species found nowhere on earth but Santa Rosa. Santa Rosa also hosts over 100 bird and three land mammal species\
column12: including the endemic island fox.      Remains of an ancient species like the pygmy mammoth have been uncovered on Santa Rosa Island. These miniature mammoths\
column13: reaching just four to six ft. tall\
column14: roamed the island&amp;#39;s grasslands and forests during the Pleistocene Age. The island has rich archeological resources as well. It is home to thousands of significant archeological sites of the Chumash Native Americans\
column15: who inhabited the island until 1820.

column8: Flowing Park (#715.1A) makes a lariat with the Indian Point (#715) trail for a 14 mile high altitude ride.  Follow tall trail marker posts for the first 2.3 miles and you'll reach the trail junction.  Clockwise is the recommended route.  The trail will get faint in some places but usually you can see more trail markers in the distance.  For the first half of the ride it is helpful to know that you're aiming out towards the edges of the Mesa - so when in doubt over the trail\
column9: aim towards views.  The middle portion of the trail is filled with lava rock and can be quite tough and anxiety inducing to ride through.  Take a hike to Indian Point once you reach the junction and enjoy those views as well.  The last 4 miles are some of the most entertaining.  At the cattle fence hang a right.

column8: This trail absolutely rocks!!!  I rode the entire thing the summer of 2003 in an epic trip that lasted five days. Granted you do not have to ride the entire trail to enjoy the picturesque riding which includes high plateaus\
column9: drainages\

column13: and plenty of winding single track to connect it all. Throw some absolutely killer climbs and long decents in the mix and whalla!!! Thats the trail in a nutshell. Every aspect of riding in one epic journey. While the trail is not overly technical it is not heavily traveled and the views make up for the lack of extremely technical riding. Do not attempt to ride this trail if it wet. It takes about ten feet for the mud to build up so much that the tires dont roll and the bike becomes about 20 pounds heavier. I rode for five days in the middle of summer and only saw three other riders besides my riding buddies. Take plenty of water\

column8: San Miguel Island has a wealth of natural and cultural treasures. Its ocean-sculpted landscape and more than 500 relatively undisturbed archeological sites\
column9: make it a valued part of the Channel Islands National Park and the National Register of Historic Places. Plus its picture-perfect hikes make it a pleasing destination for campers and day-trippers alike.       Remnants of early inhabitants date back thousands of years\
column10: and fossils of the Pygmy Mammoth have been discovered here. Hikers can take a 16-mile roundtrip hike to Point Bennett to overlook fantastic\
column11: undisturbed beaches where hundreds of seals and sea lions bask in the sun. The same rewarding hike cuts through some of the best caliche forests in the Channel Islands. The Caliche Forest is a sprawl of petrified tree roots created from deposits of calcium carbonate.
column12: Island can be reached by boat from Ventura Harbor.

column8: Newest member of the Ouachita area trails. It was built by Hot Springs Bicycle Assoc. after Water Works trails was closed due to the terrorist attack on 9/11. The trail is very wel maintained and manicured by the HSBA so it is always a pleasure to ride. The trail itself is very smooth not really rocky or technical of a trail but still a lot of fun to ride. There is only one big climb here with swtichbacks that get you almost to the top. One thing I can say about the trail is that it has one of the fastest downhills around\
column9: its one of the things i look forward to when i get a chance to go over there. The rest of the trail meanders in and out of coves and small valleys with some tight areas of twists and turns along the way. A couple of small creek crossings and some nice open areas to get up some speed. There can be a few muddy spots after a rain but the HSBA is building some boardwalks over these areas. If you are in teh Hot Springs area take the time to ride this trail as I know you will be glad you did. (initially submitted by Kenny Davis)

column10: timbered countryside. Barren River Lake is located in southcentral Kentucky and is approximately 35 miles south of the largest cave system in the world\

The lake was completed by the Corps of Engineers in 1964.Barren River Lake is the site for the 2001 International (Scottish) Highland Games (the Glasgow Highland Games are held annually at the State Resort Park). The Lake area has many federally protected Native American village and burial sites.  The river was the historic route for westward traveling pioneers.  They would travel down the Barren River to a trading post at present-day Bowling Green\
column12: Kentucky\
column13: where their journey would proceed by land.For camping reservations at this and other Corps campgrounds\

many backpackers agree that this section of the Pacific Crest Trail has some of the finest mountain scenery in the United States! Much of this section of the PCT follows the massively-popular <a href="http://www.tripleblaze.com/3/323/Hiking-Trails/John-Muir-Trail.html">John Muir Trail</a>.

column8: Furnace Creek Campground is in a central location in Death Valley National Park. It is popular for RV and group camping; tent sites are also available. A visitor center\
column9: bike path\
column10: hiking trails and an abandoned borax mine are nearby.      Death Valley is one of the lowest areas of land on Earth; Furnace Creek is at an elevation of 196 ft. below sea level. The region is generally sunny\
column11: dry and clear throughout the year. Winter (November through March) is the park&amp;#39;s peak season; temperatures are mild with occasional winter storms\
column12: and visitors should bring warm clothing and light or medium jackets. Summers are known for their extremely hot and dry conditions; temperatures can soar up to 120 degrees.  Sun-protective clothing and a broad brimmed hat are recommended. Rainfall averages less than two inches per year.      Furnace Creek is the only campground in the park that takes reservations. Weekends over the winter holidays and spring break book up early; visitors should consider weekday reservations if their desired weekend is full.

You can access the west end of the trail from the center of the Joyce Piedmont Road just south of the Joyce Crescent School or farther west at the Spruce Railroad Trail trailhead on Lake Crescent where you would ride back to the east across the Lyre River bridge and turn south up the Lyre River gravel road for 3 miles to intersect the west end of the singletrack trail.

column8: The Big Mtn has some great trails and some a very technical downhill. I like to ride the main trail from the village to the summit. It's 8 miles and climbs 2000 ft through beautiful alpine forest. The trail is graded and climbs gradually with many switchbacks. It is granny gear in many spots but mostly I'm in my second ring and using my first 4 gears. Anything under 1.5 hours is good IMO but if you want to just take your time this is a great place to enjoy the spectacular views of the Flathead Valley below and Glacier Park to the east. In July and August you can stop and pick fresh huckleberries that line the trail. Once you reach the summit there is a resturant and bar with a great deck with views of the Canadian Rockies and Glacier Park. You have the option of riding the chair lift down with your bike free if you don't like downhill. (what?! are you crazy?!!!) Or you can ride the 8 mile downhill for a hell of a thrill! Also you can buy a day pass for $17 to haul you and your bike up on the chair if you just want to downhill all day. Lots of other good biking in this area as well. I lived there for 8 years...........
column9: Take US 93 N into Whitefish turn left on Baker and follow the signs to Big Mtn Ski area. Big Mtn Rd will end in the ski village. When you get there you will see the ski and bike shop. column8:
Hellroaring Peak offers backcountry lines for downhill skiing and snowboarding which are easily accessible from Whitefish Mountain Resort (Big Mountain). <br />
<br />
To get there\
column9: from the summit of Big Mountain take the cat track out around the far side of Hellroaring basin. Assuming it's already part way through the season\
column10: there should be an obvious trail blazed out the side of the resort into the backcountry. Follow this traverse a ways. Eventually\
column11: it will dump out into a snowmobile trail. Continue to follow this trail for a ways\
column12: and you will see Hellroaring Peak as you approach it. Eventually another traverse will split off of the snowmobile trail--jump on that. That trail will split\
column13: and a steep skin track/boot pack will climb up one way to the top of Hellroaring Peak\
column14: and a traverse will continue out onto into the middle of the main face. If you want maximum elevation and the best views\
column15: hike to the top\
column16: but the upper section of skiing before you cross the traverse isn't very steep. The grade steepens below the traverse\
column17: so most of the best skiing is accessible with rather minimal effort. Shred down the face and enjoy the pow! As you enter the trees below\
column18: follow the tracks and try to bear roughly to the left\
column19: and you should be able to reenter the resort at the bottom of Hellroaring Basin\
column20: catching the Hellroaring chair back out.
column21: \N

and for current trail conditions. (803) 776-4396.<br />
THE ROUTE:<br />
Starting at the After Hours parking lot - Bluff Trail to the elevated boardwalk.<br />
Left on elevated boardwalk to Weston Lake.<br />
Left on Weston Lake Loop Trail.<br />
Left on Kingsnake Trail.<br />
Travel out-and-back on Kingsnake Trail.<br />
Straight on Oakridge Trail at Bridge I.<br />
CAMP. Bridge G on the Oakridge Trail is exactly the half way mark (11.6 miles). You will want to discuss camping opportunities in this area with the rangers when you obtain your permit.<br />
Left on River Trail.<br />
Complete River Trail loop and return.<br />
Left at River Trail and Oakridge Trail junction.<br />
Right on Weston Lake Loop Trail.<br />
Continue back to Weston Lake.<br />
Left on low boardwalk.<br />
Complete low boardwalk\
column19:
heading in the direction of the visitors center.<br />
Left on Bluff Trail\
column20:
departing boardwalk before reaching the visitors center.<br />
End at the After Hours parking lot.<br />
Congratulations! You have walked on every trail in the park except the Sims Trail\
column21: which is really a road anyway.  No big deal\
column22:
right?<br />
This route is only a suggestion. Once you see the trail map you will know the variations available. I suggest this route\
column23: however\
column24:
because it is pretty simple to follow and it has a nice flow through the park.<br />
There is one more thing about this route that is interesting. You only have to carry your backpack on 9.7 of the 23.2 miles. You can dump your pack prior to the Kingsnake Trail at bridge I\
column25:
and then again prior to the River Trail around bridge F. Use caution hiding your pack and inspect it for snakes upon return.<br />

column8:
Schoodic Mountain
Schoodic Mt. can be climbed as a loop (2.8 miles) or an up and back (2.5 miles). Allow 2 hours. The mountain's summit is bare and flat with 360 degree views\
column9: including dramatic views over Frenchman Bay and Mount Desert Island. The most direct route up Schoodic Mountain leaves from the rear of the Schoodic Beach parking area. However\
column10: a popular route on a hot summer day combines an ascent from the parking area with a descent to Schoodic Beach for a refreshing swim before the half-mile walk back to the parking area. The western half of Schoodic Mountain's summit\
column11: including the communications tower\
column12:
is private property. Please respect our neighbors and stay on marked trails.

Black Mountain
The Black Mountain Cliffs Loop (2.9 miles - allow 2 hours) starts at the Schoodic Beach parking area\
column13: a popular trailhead leading to Schoodic Mountain\
column14: Schoodic Beach on Donnell Pond\
column15:
and Black Mountain. The loop includes a roughly half-mile walk to Schoodic Beach from the parking area as well as 2.4 miles of hiking trail leading up to and back from the cliffs on the southwest flank of Black Mt. The loop also offers a trail link to Black Mt.'s western summit and the Caribou Loop Trail.

The Big Chief Trail (2.6 miles - allow 2 hours) on Black Mountain starts 2.2 miles down the Black Mountain Road\
column16:
at a small trailhead parking area. It climbs steadily for approximately 0.6 miles through mixed woods and transitions into spruce and fir shortly before crossing onto open ledges with extensive views over the southern half of Tunk Lake and on towards the coast. A 1.4 mile loop around tiny Wizard Pond using a portion of the interconnected Caribou Loop Trail includes a stop atop Black Mt.'s attractive East Peak before returning to the 0.6 mile trail segment leading back to the trailhead.

Caribou Loop Trail
The Caribou Loop Trail (minimum 7 miles - allow 6-8 hours) ties together rugged Black and Caribou Mountains to create over 6 miles of backcountry hiking in Downeast Maine. The core loop is 6.1 miles\
column17: though hikers will need to add at least 0.9 miles of trail (one-way) to reach the core loop. Multiple access points mean that hikers can combine different sections of the loop into unique experiences. Access points include the Schoodic Beach/Mt. and Big Chief trailheads as well as the Caribou Mt. Trail\
column18:
a 0.9 mile trail located approximately 1 mile down the Dynamite Brook Rd (accessed off Rt. 182 between Franklin and Cherryfield).

Tunk Mountain
The new Tunk Mt. and Hidden Ponds Trails provide the opportunity to explore scenic ponds and climb a low but brawny mountain with inspiring views.

The Tunk Mt. Trail (3.2 miles roundtrip - allow 3 hours) is an up and back hike involving some steep climbing once above Mud Pond (reached at approximately 0.7 miles). Several vista points with wide-ranging views southward are encountered on the climb. The upper summit area\
column19: including a vista northward\
column20:
is on property owned by the Nature Conservancy.

The Hidden Ponds Trail (2 miles roundtrip - allow 1-2 hours) uses the first half-mile of the Tunk Mt. Trail and then loops for one mile around Salmon Pond. This trail\
column21: while still involving travel over rocks\
column22: roots\
column23:
and bog-bridging does not include significant climbing. It passes by Salmon and Little Long Pond while being only a short walk from Mud Pond (via the main Tunk Mt. Trail). An interpretive brochure further describing the trail's ecology and geology can be downloaded. The Tunk Mt./Hidden Ponds Trailhead is accessed off Rt. 182 between Franklin and Cherryfield. Hikers can link in to the Caribou Loop Trail by walking south on the Dynamite Brook Rd. for roughly one mile.

Downeast Sunrise Trail
The Downeast Sunrise Trail is an 85-mile scenic rail trail running along the entire Downeast coastal area connecting multiple scenic conservation areas\
column24: intersecting salmon rivers\
column25: and providing year round recreation opportunities. It is open to snowmobiles\
column32: and joggers. Between Franklin and Cherryfield (where there are parking areas/trailheads)\
column33: it passes through several sections of the Donnell Pond Public Lands. Shared-use roads open to vehicular and recreational trail use link the Sunrise Trail with other destinations within Donnell Pond Public Lands.
column34: Access is twelve miles east of Ellsworth off Route 182 or 183.

column9: this is my favorite hot weather trail.Deerfield lake is located about 20 miles from Rapid City and the interstate.It is the highest lake in the hills so when the temp is scorching down on the plains you can come up here in the 80 degree air and ride the trail around the lake for a great and challenging loop.The trail runs thru a forest service campground. it is best ridden counterclock-wise from lake elevation.You are then rewarded with a long and fast downhill to a secluded beach unseable just yards away from the regular beach area.Catch a pail full of crawdads out of the clear lake and have a feast at your campsite.The trail is all singletrack and for more advanced riders.It offers some tight switchbacks to open sections leading thru high country meadows.

column8:
Imagine walking across a prairie and viewing scenery similar to that seen by Black Hills pioneers in the 1890s. Such landscapes can be seen from the 30 miles of hiking trails in Wind Cave National Park. From these trails you can view one of the best examples of mixed-grass prairie in the United States. Seventy percent of the park is mixed-grass prairie and the balance is ponderosa pine forest and riparian habitat.<br />
Source: National Park Service

column8: You made it to the drainage pipe now muster up some courage and ride through it. You may have to walk a few feet once you leave the pipe. The trail climbs out of the wash on the left and when it crosses the wash again take the trail on the left up onto slickrock. Now follow the cairns and old painted dashes on the rock. Follow the trail towards Church Rocks along the rim then drop into the valley and head back to the trail you can make another loop or head back down to the wash and to the pipe that brought you there.
column9: From I-15 get off at Highway 9(this goes to Hurricane and Zion National Park) Immediately after exiting I-15 head towards Hurricane and go right onto Coral Canyon road(if you pass the golf course turn around) and follow it down to the stop sign and hang a left until you see Heritage Park then find a place to park. Head north(toward I-15) on the road next to the parking lot for Heritage Park and look for a paved bike path on the right. Follow the bike path up to a water tank on top of the hill by the freeway. Head down a dirt road on the back side of the tank and then take an immediate right on a dirt track and look for a drainage pipe that goes under the freeway. The trail starts here.

column8: The trail leaving the parking area is a wide track for about the first quarter mile until a signed intersection where you will turn left (south) onto singletrack and start your ride parallel to some red rock ledges. The trail is fairly smooth and has nice flow as it crosses up and over small ridges and down through gullies. A couple spots have been rerouted for vegetation rehabilitation but these are clearly marked. At about 1.7 miles you will run into a very sandy hill\
column9: this sand section will last just about 100 yards and then is done\
column10: in the middle of it is an intersection with the Spanish Wash trail\
column11: any equestrian traffic that has been on the trail will more than likely exit here. Continuing on stay right on the main trail when you encounter a small singletrack that takes off to the left. The intersection with the Church Rocks trail will be an obvious T\
column12: although ride-able either direction I recommend taking a right and doing the loop counter-clockwise. You will ride back towards the north for about a mile but higher up on the hillside so there are more slickrock sections mixed in. You will come to a large U turn and the trail goes up a short but steep rock section and then takes off south up the ledge. Once on top you have over a mile of slick rock ledges and bowls to play in all the while making your way south down the ridge. Upon reaching the end you will all of a sudden notice large black volcanic rocks strewn about\
column13: these are very evident because all you have seen for the last hour or so has been red. Its advisable to go down the wash to get off of the ridge and start heading back north. Once at the bottom you will notice a couple other trails\

column8: Wind Cave National Park was the seventh US national park to be designated and was the first cave the world over to be designated as a national park. It is currently the 5th largest in the world\
column9:
with 137.02 miles of discovered passages (and more being discovered each year). It is considered a three-dimensional maze cave due to the highest concentration of passages in a cubic mile of any cave in the world.<br />
Notable speleothems include boxwork (Wind Cave has 95% of the world's discovered boxwork) and frostwork. Boxwork is a calcite speleogen that forms when the walls of a cave erode away but the hardened calcite does not\
column10:
leaving a boxlike honeycomb structure on the walls and roof.<br />
The cave is open year-round (excluding holidays).

column8: Jewel Cave\
column9: located in Jewel Cave National Monument\
column10: is officially the second-longest mapped cave in the world (behind Mammoth Caverns in Kentucky) with a length of 157 miles. Because of the length\
column11: it takes explorers a significant amount of time to reach the unexplored portions of the cavern\
column12: oftentimes requiring camping underground on expeditions of 4 or more days in length. According to Wikipedia\
column13:
"The discovered areas in the cave account for only about 2% of the estimated total air volume of the cave. The cave volume is estimated by measuring the amount of air that the cave "exhales" when the outside air pressure drops and "inhales" when the outside air pressure rises." <br />
Jewel Cave contains all of the traditional speleothems\
column14: although not in as high of quantities as some other well-known caverns. Some of the unique formations include a hydromagnesite balloon\
column15:
which is formed by a gas inflating this substance.<br />

column8: Section H of the PCT trail runs 175.8 miles from Mt. Whitney to Tuolumne Meadows and Highway 120. Mt. Whitney is the highest point on the entire Pacific Crest Trail with an elevation of 14\

many backpackers agree that this section of the Pacific Crest Trail has some of the finest mountain scenery in the United States! Much of this section of the PCT follows the massively-popular <a href="http://www.tripleblaze.com/3/323/Hiking-Trails/John-Muir-Trail.html">John Muir Trail</a>.

column8: The Elephant Head Mountain Bike Route is a combination of little-traveled roads and remote trails designed especially for these versatile\
column9: muscle-powered vehicles. Winding across the scenic foothills of the Santa Rita Mountains in the shadow of the dramatic landmark for which it was named\
column10: the route was designed both to challenge a rider's skill and to provide a scenic\
column11:
backcountry experience.

One end of the ride is at the mouth of Madera Canyon Recreation Area. The other is at the Fred Lawrence Whipple Observatory Visitor Center on the road to the top of Mount Hopkins.

From the Madera Canyon trailhead\
column12: the ride follows old jeep tracks across the desert grasslands and mesquite flats to the base of Elephant Head Rock\
column13: where it turns into a single-track trail. As the trail curls around the Rock\
column14:
it heads up Chino Canyon into Chino Basin along a steep old mining road.

At the top of the climb to Chino Basin\
column15: the ride turns south along a rugged mountain trail over a saddle then down a nice grade into Agua Caliente Canyon. After crossing Agua Caliente Creek\
column16:
the route leads along a couple of little-used forest roads around a couple of foothills that mark the western limits of the Santa Rita Range. The ride ends at the Whipple Observatory Visitors Center where water and restrooms are available. Or you can just make a quick turn around in the parking lot and do it all over again in the opposite direction.

Equestrians and hikers also use this trail\
column17: and vehicles use the 4-wheel drive roads\
column18:
so be alert for hazards.

column8: (NB: my odometer was acting funny on this trip\
column9: so take my distance measurements as estimates.) You can ride this loop clockwise or counterclockwise; I recommend going counterclockwise to take advantage of the Snowslide Trail downhill.  Starting from the bottom of the Snowslide trail\
column10: ride up thru the recreation area to the trailhead for the Cisneros trail\
column11: or just ride thru the group campground at the end of the road\
column12: which also will get you onto the Cisneros.  Begin climbing.  Iím not big on grunting uphill\
column13: and Iím even less thrilled about pushing my bike up a trail.  While it is possible to ride up the Cisneros if you are a man of steel\
column14: most people will probably end up pushing.  And pushing.  And pushingÖ  By the time I got to the top of the trail I think I pushed a good three miles or more.  Yuck. There is a steep section in the middle that goes on for a couple miles with lots of altitude gain.  Then\
column15: after cresting the ridge there is a very pleasant mile and a half or so of gentle uphill thru a meadow area.  Then you encounter a steeper and more heavily bouldered trail that will often force you off the saddle.  After picking up nearly three thousand vertical feet in about nine miles or so you will come to the Greenhorn Mountain Rd (FR369).  Take a left (south) and go about a mile and a half till you see the sign for the Snowslide Trail.  Go to the left (east) uphill till you finally crest out at the top.  You probably have pedaled close to eleven miles to get to that point.  The views are great.  To the north you have a clear view of Pikeís Peak.  To the northeast you will see the city of Pueblo.  Now comes the payoff.  The downhill portion of Snowslide Trail is rocky\
column16: steep\
column17: narrow\
column18: twisting\
column19: root infested\
column20: and challenging.  In other words\
column21: a *lot* of fun.  It took nearly eleven miles of uphill to get to the top ñ you will get to the bottom in about four miles.  Get it?  Steep.  Not far from the top is a nasty\
column22: technical section. The hardcore riders will be grinning; everybody else will be dreading what is to come.  Donít worry\
column23: it only lasts a hundred yards or so.  After that the trail is mostly rideable by anyone with good technical skills.  What a blast!  Note that near the bottom the trail forks.  Go left if you parked in the recreation area; go right if you parked on the highway. Picking a rating for this trail was difficult to me.  As I was pushing my way up the Cisneros\
column24: the number kept decreasing\
column25: but by the time I got to the bottom of the Snowslide Trail my rating jumped back up.  If you donít mind long uphills then you probably will feel it is worth a try.  Oh\
column26: if you donít want to push your way up the Cisneros\
column27: and you have a ground crew\
column28: you could just have them drive you to the top of Snowslide.

column8: The Telegraph Trail System is a fantastic riding area located virtually in town! The "Trails 2000" organization has done a great job building and maintaining these trails. These are the trails that your bike is begging you to take a ride on! The Telegraph Trails are laid out in multiple loops with multiple trail heads that allow you to combine trails and mileage to match your desires. In and out of canyons and meadows with Scrub Oak\
column9:
Juniper and Pine on great single track. The switchbacks in and out of the canyons get the legs to burning but are short and manageable. Each intersection has "You Are Here" maps so you always know where you are. There is no specific direction or route you must take (go ahead and create your own) but a favorite 10-mile combination loop we enjoy starts at the Sale Barn trail head and ends at the Big Canyon trail head with a short frontage road ride back to the car.<br />
From the Sale Barn trail head follow the Sale Barn trail through a couple of canyons and meadows and turn right at the first intersection onto the Cowboy trail. Follow this trail up to intersection 2 and turn right again\
column10: staying on the Cowboy trail. Turn left at intersection 3 and turn left at intersection 4 onto the Sidewinder trail. Breeze along the Sidewinder trail and turn left at intersection 5 and again left at intersection 6 onto the South Rim trail. Great views of the South side of Durango can be seen from along this ridge. Continue around and down on the South Rim trail until intersection 7 and turn right onto the Big Canyon trail. Blast down a great finishing stretch that drops you in and out of creek beds until you finally reach the bottom and the Big Canyon trail head. Turn left on the frontage road and cool down on the ride back you your car. Be sure to watch for hikers\
column11: horses and other bikers.<br />
column12: The Sale Barn trail head is located across from the Home Depot on US550/160 (S Camino Del Rio) at the Southern end of Durango. There is a sign at the turnoff from the highway onto a frontage road. Pull into the gravel parking lot up the hill on the right.

column8:
Overend Mountain Park is named after Durangos favorite son and local <br />
bicycle folk hero\
column9:
Ned Overend. Its conveniently located right at the edge <br />
of Durango\
column10:
so you can easily get out for a quick and fun single-track <br />
experience when youre in Durango.<br />
<br />
The network is well marked with signs at major junctions\
column11:
so just remember <br />
the names of the trails you want to hit. There are trails that exit the park <br />
and go off the map out onto BLM land if you are looking for a longer <br />
adventure.<br />
<br />
There are multiple loop options you can explore after you are familiar. To <br />
get you familiar\
column12:
heres a fun five-mile route. From either of the suggested <br />
trailheads\
column13:
turn right (north) onto Crestview Tr. Turn left onto Hidden Valley <br />
Trail. Turn right on Grabens Loop (staying left at the unmarked junction). <br />
At the next sign\
column14: turn right for a fun\
column15:
banked descent down Star Wars. Turn <br />
right on Perins Gulch for a nice climb up to Hogsback. Follow the ridge until <br />
you are faced with an OMG-Durango-gnarly climb. Go up and over the top if <br />
you are an over-the-top gonzo rider. Saner folks can shake their heads in <br />
disbelief and turn around here and retrace your route back to Perins Gulch. <br />
Stay on Perins Gulch until you can turn left and climb the lower half of Neds <br />
Hill. If you are out for a shorter ride\
column16:
turn right on Engleharts Trail and <br />
another right onto Crestview to return to your car. If you want to extend <br />
your fun\
column17:
dont turn onto Engleharts Tr. But continue up Neds Hill Trail. <br />
Turn left on Grabens Loop. You can choose to do Star Wars again if you <br />
liked that. Otherwise\
column18:
complete Grabens Loop and take Hidden Valley back <br />
around to Crestview Trail and your car.<br />

column9: Section L of the Pacific Crest Trail is the final section of the trail in Washington\
column10: and consequently the final section for the entire trail. This section runs 70.3 miles from Highway 20 at Rainy Pass\
column11: across the American/Canadian Border\
column12: and ends at Highway 3 in Manning Park in British Columbia. Much of this section lies far to the east of the Cascades. As a result\
column13: this section receives much less snow than Mt. Baker (one of the snowiest places on the planet)\
column14:
but it can still be snow covered into the late summer. <br />
<br />
Along the way this section of trail passes Porcupine Creek; Cutthroat Pass; Granite Pass; Methow Pass; Golden Creek; West Fork Methow River; Glacier Pass; Alpine-garden pass above South Fork Trout Creek; Harts Pass; Buffalo Pass; Windy Pass; Foggy Pass; Jim Pass; Devils Backbone; Holman Pass; alternate PCT route; Hopkins Pass; Castle Pass; Monument 78\
column15: United States-Canada Border; Castle Creek; Windy Joe Mountain; old PCT route; and Manning Park Lodge.

according to the official PCT guide book.<br />

column8:
We went down to Durango for the day and it just so happened that the Iron Horse Classic was in
town. We watched a couple of criterium races then headed for the nearest singletrack just
outside town at Dry Fork. There were a couple of horse trailers in the trailhead parking lot\
column9:
never
a good sign for bikers. Fortunately\
column10:
one group of horseback riders was coming off the trail as we
geared up and we never saw the other group. The signs at the trailhead warn riders to avoid the
trail when things are wet but we quickly realized by looking at the trail conditions that this
warning is rarely heeded. The tread is hard and bumpy with hoof prints and solidified tire tracks\
column11: relics of muddier times. The climb wasn't too difficult\
column12:
though we probably went around the loop
in the wrong direction based on the number of riders we saw coming the other way (in our
defense we decided on the counter-clockwise route after viewing the trailhead map and elevation
profile which seemed to indicate that this was the way to go). The scenery was great\
column13:
lots of wild
flowers and a few nice aspen groves near the top. The return down was great\
column14:
a little bumpy
with rocks and roots at times. Check it out if you're in the area\
column15:
the singletrack doesn't
disappoint.
column16: From Durango\
column17: take US 160 West about 3 miles and turn right onto Lightner Creek Road (County <br />Road 207).  Go about a mile and turn right onto Dry Fork Road (County Road 208).  After about 2 <br />miles\
column18: go right at the Y intersection\
column19: park at the trailhead on the left after about a mile.  Ride up <br />the trail and take the left turn at the first intersection onto Dry Fork trail.  When you hit the <br />Colorado Trail\
column20: take a right\
column21: then a right onto Hoffheins to complete the loop.  You'll climb about <br />1200 feet over the 4 or 5 miles to the top.

column8: Skagit Valley Provincial Park is a 69\
column9: 100-acre provincial park just south of Hope and north of the US/Canadian border. This park is a popular destination and has facilities for hiking\

column11: horseback riding\
column12: boating\

column17: The Silver/Skagit Road\
column18: which joins Highway #1 three kilometres west of Hope\
column19: provides access to the Park. It is 37 km from Highway #1 to the entrance portal and a further 23 km to Ross Lake Reservoir and the Canada-USA border.<br />The Silver/Skagit Road is a well maintained\
column20: loose surface road that provides access to several active logging areas before the Park entrance. Motorists are advised to drive with extreme caution and to use headlights at all times. Watch for wildlife and be aware of logging trucks and other industrial equipment. Extra caution should be taken after rain when road surfaces can become muddy and slippery.

column8: The North Cascades National Park Service Complex preserves some of the finest mountain country in North America-a hiker's smorgasbord. From accessible trails and short\
column9: scenic strolls to steep\
column10: grueling hikes that will make your legs burn but your heart sing\
column11: there is a trail here that will suit your mood. The extreme gradients of climate and topography contribute to an impressive diversity of habitat and species. To navigate the incredibly steep elevational relief\
column12: the nearly 400 miles of trails often follow the long\
column13: forested\
column14: valley bottoms\
column15: then switchback up to the steep passes or ridges. Over 300 glaciers cling to the spires\
column16: peaks\
column17: horns and ridges of the surrounding mountains\
column18: and more than 127 alpine lakes lie in glacial cirque basins below. The valleys are narrow\
column19: deep\
column20: and U-shaped\
column21:
covered on the lower reaches with dense stands of old trees and layers of green undergrowth.<br />
Source: National Park Service

column8: âThe Whoopsâ is a compilation of 3 trails in the Glade Run Trails area North of Farmington\
column9: NM. The area is criss crossed with many interesting trails and this is a fun\
column10: 9-mile\
column11:
figure 8. It includes parts of the famous âRoad Apple Trail. It rolls through the Pinon Pines and is very single speed friendly. The first 3 miles (Kinsey Trail) and the last 3 miles (Rigor Mortis Trail) are parallel to each other but are actually separate trails. There are lots of spur trails so use you odometer to watch for the turns you want to take.
From the trailhead\
column12: ride through opening in the pipe fence and stay on the trail to the right (Kinsey Trail).  @ 2.3 miles\
column13: (waypoint A) ignore spur on the left (you will turn here coming back). @ In aprox 50 yards (waypoint B) take the fork left. @ 3.7 miles\
column14: (waypoint C) take the fork to the right and start down the whoops! @ 4.2 miles\
column15: head left on the dirt road for aprox 100 yards and look for the trail on the right (waypoint D). @ 5.4 miles\
column16: take the right fork (waypoint E). @ 6.6 miles you will arrive back at waypoint B and turn left. You will be backtracking on this section for aprox 50 yards and turn onto the spur on your right (waypoint A). Follow this parallel trail (Rigor Mortis Trail) back to trailhead @ 9.0 miles. These trails are usually rideable most of the winter months.

column8: This is a very rocky\
column9: continually challenging trail.  Stephen's trail alternates between flowy singletrack and rock garden mania.  It sidehills a few miles\
column10: then you start to veer east and make the climb to the ridgetop.  The climb is nothing less than brutal in places.  The combination of grade and technical requirements will force most off their bikes a time or two\
column11: but it's a great ride.  When you hit the ridgetop\
column12: go right on the Massanutten trail.  Again\
column13: more cool singletrack and and rock gardens with an occasional view of the valley between Massanutten and Shenandoah.  There's an optional out-and-back to the top of Kennedy peak which may or may not be worth it depending on your fitness level and desire for more miles and technical riding.  Keep following the Massanuten trail--it'll turn into double track for a while before dropping you out on 675.  Never fear\
column14: upon taking a right on 675\
column15: there is an almost immediate singletrack to the right and you're right back in the woods for some very technical rutted and rocky singletrack\
column16:
some of which is just painful but most of which is just plain fun. This singletrack will deliver you back to the access road to the parking lot. <br />
This ride is a lot like it's more famous neighbor\
column17: Elizabeth Furnace.  While the last descent on Elizabeth Furnace is longer and more varied\
column18: this ride has two thing going for it over Elizabeth Furnace.  First\
column19: it's all singletrack; you don't need miles of fire road to make a legitimate loop.  Second\
column20: while there are some real technical challenges\
column21: even for advanced riders\
column22: you won't spend nearly as much time on mandatory hike-a-bikes.  It also gets a lot less traffic; well worth the extra trouble to find it.

column8:
Trail is recommend to be done as a shuttle but can be done as an out and <br />
back from trailhead on Fish Creek Road. Shuttle is easiest by parking a <br />
vehicle and the Stagecoach bar or the Gas station in Wilson. This does <br />
have you ride 3 miles of road back to the car after the trail but is easier and <br />
saves time. Driving the 3 miles from Wilson to the End is on a slow 25mph <br />
road. Trail starts about 100 yards from the hwy on the right side of road. <br />
Trail is marked. First segment is the Arrow Trail. Stay on the trail until you <br />
come to what should be your second trail junction. Take the trail to the <br />
right marked Snotel. This will lead you to another junction and sign marked <br />
for Phillips Ridge or Ridge trail head that way and enjoy your descent. <br />
Other variations are when you come to your first junction take a right onto <br />
the Ridge trail. This leads you to the same place with just a little more <br />
climbing than the Snotel trail (about same mileage). The last 1/2 mile <br />
travels through private property that is signed so be respectful. Trails also <br />
abruptly drops you out onto Fish Creek RD so be careful. All is signed well <br />
at the bottom. When you hit Fish Creek road head right back into Wilson.
column9: Trail starts on Teton Pass WY.  There is a large parking lot on the south side of <br /><br />the road or you can park along the jeep road on the north side of road.  <br /><br />Parking lots are about 3-4 miles west of Wilson WY heading towards Idaho.<br /><br />End of trail is located on Fish Creek rd about 3 miles north of Wilson WY.

column8:
There is a network of trails here. The trails are multi use. All of the trails <br />
are as wide as double track but mostly smooth. There are places where <br />
you could easily fit 3 horses shoulder to shoulder across the trail. The trails <br />
do not have any remarkable features or technical challenge. However the <br />
sheer size of the area and the moderate climbs and ripping fun downhills <br />
make this a fun trip. It isn't going to satisfy single track purists looking for a <br />
the next best trail. But everyone else would probably enjoy it IF single <br />
track is not a priority. The trails are pretty smooth overall\
column9:
a few have some <br />
baby head gardens. The climbing isn't going to force many hike a bikes but <br />
in places it is extended. The Scenery is worth mentioning. The trail system <br />
overlooks the Shenandoah river and the valley. Very nice. Camping <br />
available. State Park Fee is $3 or 4$. Previous trail description listed just <br />
Bear Bottom Loop. The size and numerous trails require a more up to date <br />
listing.

column8: This trail has it all\
column9: from beautiful forests\
column10:
good climbing and fun descents to technical sections with views of Mt. Rainier from cliffs that will inspire you.<br />
Start hiking through old growth timber. At a tenth of a mile cross Dalles Creek and for the next mile be careful as you hike through a series of short switchbacks in loose rock.<br />
You will gradually climb and cross Snoquera Creek at mile 3.7. At mile 4.7 you reach viewpoints of the White River Valley below. The next section of your hike will take you through a recent timber harvest area at mile 5.5. Another viewpoint of the valley below is just ahead at mile 5.7. At mile 6.6 is the junction with Ranger Creek Trail 1197. source: fs.usda.gov

This park is also near Shenandoah National Park which has some good hikes. <br /><br /><br /><br />From Front Royal Virginia take 340 South for eight miles. There will be a large sign on the right for Shenandoah State Park. At the gate to the park you can get a map of all the trails in the park. Also it is $3 per car.

column16: At the Intersection of Port Republic Road and South Main Street (Route 11) head South and turn <br />right at South Avenue.  Continue past South High Street and take it all the way to the end.  The last <br />intersection you reach is South Dogwood Drive\
column17: the dead end at the top of the hill is where the trail <br />begins.  Head right past the sign and turn right into the woods.

column9:
Trail is easiet down as a loop but can be done as a shuttle as well. Take a <br />
right into Teton Canyon and park at the first big parking lot on the left. <br />
About 50 yards from Ski Hill rd. Then ride you bike up Skill Hill Rd about 3.2 <br />
miles. Trail starts on your right on a jeep road. The road climb up isn't as <br />
bad as it looks (roughly 30min). After you go down the jeep road there will <br />
be a brown carsonite sign indicating a trail on your left. Take the <br />
singletrack trail and follow it. Trail will wind up and down through the forest <br />
for around 2 miles. At the trail junction in the meadow take a right. This <br />
will put you onto Mill Creek trail which leads back to Teton Canyon. Once <br />
you hit the road take a right and head back up .5-1 mile to your car.
column10: Trail starts 3 miles up Ski Hill Rd after you pass the Teton Canyon Turnoff.  <br /><br />Located about 6 miles east of Driggs\
column11: ID.  Trail is on the right at a jeep road <br /><br />turnoff.  Sometimes there is a sign that says Mill Creek (but not always). The is <br /><br />another jeep road on the left of road as well.

column8: Travel the rugged Naches Trail\
column9: following the route of the pioneer wagons in the mid-1800s over the same mountain range we now cross via Chinook Pass on Highway 410. This trail will give you an idea of the challenges faced by those determined settlers. The Naches Pass is a favorite for its beautiful scenic meadows and mountains. Spot signs of deer or elk if you are lucky.  At Government Meadows find Camp Urich\
column10: located south and a few hundred yards on the Pacific Crest 2000 Trail.  Camp Urich is a log cabin complete with a wood stove and outhouse. The cabin's use is on a first come first served basis\
column11:
and you may find yourself sharing it. <br />
The Naches Trail is crosses many roads as you climb through old growth forest and clear cuts:<br />
0.5 miles - FS road #70<br />
0.6 miles - FS road #7065<br />
1.8 miles - Weyerhaeuser Road<br />
2.6 miles - Weyerhaeuser Road<br />
3.1 miles - Weyerhaeuser Road<br />
The section of the Naches Trail from FS road 7033 to FS road 7065 (cliffs) is open to hikers only. From FS road 7065 to Naches Pass the trail is open to all.<br />
The trail continues east into the Naches Ranger District in the Okanogan-Wenatchee National Forest and becomes Naches Pass Jeep Trail 684. This ORV trail provides fair to good 4-wheeling and biking. Please contact the Naches Ranger District for current conditions at 509-653-2205. source: fs.usda.gov
column12: Drive east on State Highway 410 from Enumclaw 20.3 miles to Greenwater Road #70. Turn left (north) onto Road #70 and follow 9.6 miles to trail sign above cliffs.<br /><br />There are 20 parking spaces on the road shoulder at the trailhead.

column8: Shenandoah Caverns offers a 1 mile guided tour that travels through 17 various connected rooms. According to Wikipedia\
column9: "Geological formations have been named: the Diamond Cascade\
column10: the Grotto of the Gods\
column11: the Rainbow Lake\
column12: the Oriental Tea Garden\
column13: and the Capitol Dome\
column14:
and these are lighted for display. The "bacon" formations were featured in a 1964 issue of National Geographic Magazine.[3] The caverns' temperature naturally remains at 54 degrees year round." <br />
Shenandoah caverns is the only show cave in Virginia that offers elevator access.

column15: in-line skates and wheel chairs. It also has a soft shoulder path for equestrians.<br /><br />Completed paved sections include 15 miles from Meeker to the South Prairie Creek in South Prairie and a 1.8 mile section in Buckley. Our future plan is to continue the trail to Sumner where we will connect with the Interurban Trail that now extends through Kent and Auburn. The trail in Buckley will continue east to Enumclaw and King County.<br /><br />

column8: Grand Caverns is the United States' oldest show cave\
column9: having been in business since 1806. The cave is 3.78 miles long and features numerous speleothems\
column10: including an unusual number of unusually high-quality shield formations. According to Wikipedia\
column11: "It is also replete with stalactites\
column12: stalagmites\
column13: columns (where stalactites and stalagmites meet)\
column14: draperies and other flowstone formations. The most stately room\
column15: "Cathedral Hall"\
column16: is 280 feet long and over 70 feet (21 m) high. It is one of the largest rooms of any cavern in the Eastern United States. Other sights include "Bridal Veil"\
column17: "Stonewall Jackson's Horse"\
column18: the "Tapestry Room"\
column19: and "Dante's Inferno"."

column8: This is a tough trail that will challenge even the best mountain bikers. This trail is rocky and steep in certain sections\
column9: and some wet areas are quite difficult after a horse trail ride has been through. The Duncan Hollow Trail (part of the orange blazed Massanutten East Trail) starts on Route 675 just east of the entrance to Camp Roosevelt behind the pullout for sewage disposal. There is a sign for the trail on Route 675. The trail begins as a single track\
column10: rolling trail that crosses many damp ditches. At about mile 0.3\
column11: the trail joins a service road (after about 3 miles youíll see the Gap Creek Trail off to the right). The early part of the trail is very rocky and can be Extremely Muddy after wet weather. After about 4.8 miles\
column12: you will travel down a steep rocky hill which is dangerous to the novice mountain biker. At the base of the hill\
column13: turn right on the Middle Mountain Trail and follow the yellow blazes for 0.6 miles to merge with the Scothorn Gap Trail. Veer right to hook up with this red blazed trail. Follow this trail for 1.4 miles and take a left hand turn onto Gap Creek Trail. This is a muddy\
column14: rocky trail that switches back and forth down the hill for 0.8 miles. Cross the stream and turn right onto Crismon Hollow Road (Forest Service Road 274) and follow for 3.1 miles. This hard packed gravel road is very pleasant and will go by quickly. Turn right on Route 675 and continue for 0.3 miles back to the dump station.
column15: Starting at exit 307 off of I-81 in Stephens City\
column16: drive south on Interstate 81 for 28 miles and exit at Edinburg (exit 279). Turn left onto Route 675 and drive east 0.8 miles to the intersection with Route 11. Turn left and drive north on Route 11 for 0.5 miles and turn right again onto Route 675. Drive 5.8 miles over Edinburg Gap into Fort Valley to Kingís Crossing. Bear right and continue on Route 675 for 3.5 miles to the entrance to Camp Roosevelt. Park in the picnic area lot.

column8:
Bovine trail is part of a larger system. You can use it to access more trails or <br />
make it your end destination from other trailheads. It is a steep climb but <br />
returns the favor with a fast downhill. Usually one of the first trails to open in <br />
the spring and last to close in the fall.
column9: At the stoplight in Driggs head west.  When the road curves south continue <br /><br />straight.  The main road will curve north and then west again heading into <br /><br />Horseshoe Canyon.   After you cross the forest service boundary (second <br /><br />cattle guard) go another mile.  There will be a jeep road on the right.  Take <br /><br />the turn and go about 100 yards there will be a parking lot on your left.  <br /><br />Signed trail head is across from parking area.
